CollectionChoiceFeature.Name: Fighting Style
CollectionChoiceFeature.Text: You adopt a particular style of fighting as your specialty. Choose one of the following options. You can’t take a Fighting Style option more than once, even if you later get to choose again.

ResourceFeature.Name: Second Wind
ResourceFeature.Text: You have a limited well of stamina that you can draw on to protect yourself from harm. On your turn, you can use a bonus action to regain hit points equal to 1d10 + your fighter level. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

ResourceFeature.Name: Action Surge
ResourceFeature.Text: Starting at 2nd level, you can push yourself beyond your normal limits for a moment. On your turn, you can take one additional action on top of your regular action and a possible bonus action. Once you use this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again. Starting at 17th level, you can use it twice before a rest, but only once on the same turn.

SubClassFeature.Name: Martial Archetype
SubClassFeature.Text: At 3rd level, a fighter gains the Martial Archetype feature. The following options are available to a fighter, in addition to those offered in the Player’s Handbook: the Arcane Archer, the Cavalier, and the Samurai.

AbilityScoreFeatFeature.Name: Ability Score Improvement
AbilityScoreFeatFeature.Text: When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

ExtraAttackFeature.Name: Extra Attack
ExtraAttackFeature.Text: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn. The number of attacks increases to three when you reach 11th level in this class and to four when you reach 20th level in this class.

ResourceFeature.Name: Indomitable
ResourceFeature.Text: Beginning at 9th level, you can reroll a saving throw that you fail. If you do so, you must use the new roll, and you can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest. You can use this feature twice between long rests starting at 13th level and three times between long rests starting at 17th level.

ToolKWProficiencyFeature.Name: Multiclassing Proficiencies:
ToolKWProficiencyFeature.Text: Light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons
ToolKWProficiencyFeature.Condition: (Armor and (Light or Medium)) or Shield or (Weapon and (Simple or Martial))
ToolKWProficiencyFeature.Description: Light armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons

SkillProficiencyChoiceFeature.Name: Skills
SkillProficiencyChoiceFeature.Text: Choose two skills from Acrobatics, Animal Handling, Athletics, History, Insight, Intimidation, Perception, and Survival

ChoiceFeature.Name: Equipment
ChoiceFeature.Text: (a) chain mail or (b) leather, longbow, and 20 arrows

ChoiceFeature.Name: Equipment
ChoiceFeature.Text: (a) a martial weapon and a shield or (b) two martial weapons

MultiFeature.Name: A martial weapon and a shield
MultiFeature.Text: A martial weapon and a shield

ChoiceFeature.Name: Equipment
ChoiceFeature.Text: (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) two handaxes

ItemChoiceFeature.Name: Equipment
ItemChoiceFeature.Text: (a) a dungeoneer’s pack or (b) an explorer’s pack

ClassDefinition.Name: Fighter
ClassDefinition.Description: Of all the adventurers in the worlds of D&D, the fighter is perhaps the greatest paradox. On the one hand, a singular feature of the class is that no two fighters ply their craft in quite the same way; their weapons, armor, and tactics differ across a vast spectrum. On the other hand, regardless of the tools and methods one uses, at the heart of every fighter’s motivation lies the same basic truth: it is better to wound than to be wounded. Although some adventuring fighters risk their lives fighting for glory or treasure, others are primarily concerned with the welfare of others. They put more value on the well-being of the society, the village, or the group than on their own safety. Even if there’s gold in the offing, the true reward for most fighters comes from sending enemies to their doom. The sections below offer ways to add a little depth and a few personal touches to your fighter character.
ClassDefinition.Flavour: Let me know when you’re all done talking. — Tordek

TableDescription.Name: Heraldic Sign
TableDescription.Text: Fighters typically do battle for a cause. Some fight on behalf of kingdoms besieged by monsters, while others quest only for personal glory. In either case, a fighter often displays a heraldic sign that represents that cause, either adopting the symbol of a nation or a royal line, or creating a crest to represent one’s self-interest. Your character could be affiliated with an organization or a cause, and thus might already travel under a banner of some sort. If that’s not the case, consider devising a heraldic sign that symbolizes an aspect of your nature or speaks to what you see as your purpose in the world.

TableEntry.Text: A rampant golden dragon on a green field, representing valor and a quest for wealth
The fist of a storm giant clutching lightning before a storm cloud, symbolizing wrath and power
Crossed greatswords in front of a castle gate, signifying the defense of a city or kingdom
A skull with a dagger through it, representing the doom you bring to your enemies
A phoenix in a ring of fire, an expression of an indomitable spirit
Three drops of blood beneath a horizontal sword blade on a black background, symbolizing three foes you have sworn to kill

TableDescription.Name: Instructor
TableDescription.Text: Some fighters are natural-born combatants who have a talent for surviving in battle. Others learned the basics of their combat prowess in their formative years from spending time in a military or some other martial organization, when they were taught by the leaders of the group. A third type of fighter comes from the ranks of those who received one-on-one instruction from an accomplished veteran of the craft. That instructor was, or perhaps still is, well versed in a certain aspect of combat that relates to the student’s background. If you decide that your character had an individual instructor, what is that person’s specialty? Do you emulate your instructor in how you fight, or did you take the instructor’s teachings and adapt them to your own purposes?

TableEntry.Title: Gladiator
TableEntry.Text: Your instructor was a slave who fought for freedom in the arena, or one who willingly chose the gladiator’s life to earn money and fame.

TableEntry.Title: Military
TableEntry.Text: Your trainer served with a group of soldiers and knows much about working as a team.

TableEntry.Title: City Watch
TableEntry.Text: Crowd control and peacekeeping are your instructor’s specialties.

TableEntry.Title: Tribal Warrior
TableEntry.Text: Your instructor grew up in a tribe, where fighting for one’s life was practically an everyday occurrence.

TableEntry.Title: Street Fighter
TableEntry.Text: Your trainer excels at urban combat, combining close-quarters work with silence and efficiency.

TableEntry.Title: Weapon Master
TableEntry.Text: Your mentor helped you to become one with your chosen weapon, by imparting highly specialized knowledge of how to wield it most effectively.

TableDescription.Name: Signature Style
TableDescription.Text: Many fighters distinguish themselves from their peers by adopting and perfecting a particular style or method of waging combat. Although this style might be a natural outgrowth of a fighter’s personality, that’s not always the case — someone’s approach to the world in general does not necessarily dictate how that person operates when lives are on the line. Do you have a combat style that mirrors your outlook on life, or is something else inside you unleashed when weapons are drawn?

TableEntry.Title: Elegant
TableEntry.Text: You move with precise grace and total control, never using more energy than you need.

TableEntry.Title: Brutal
TableEntry.Text: Your attacks rain down like hammer blows, meant to splinter bone or send blood flying.

TableEntry.Title: Cunning
TableEntry.Text: You dart in to attack at just the right moment and use small-scale tactics to tilt the odds in your favor.

TableEntry.Title: Effortless
TableEntry.Text: You rarely perspire or display anything other than a stoic expression in battle.

TableEntry.Title: Energetic
TableEntry.Text: You sing and laugh during combat as your spirit soars. You are happiest when you have a foe in front of you and a weapon in hand.

TableEntry.Title: Sinister
TableEntry.Text: You scowl and sneer while fighting, and you enjoy mocking your foes as you defeat them.
